description: This course aims to introduce you to the basics of interpersonal communication and public speaking. In particular, emphasis will be placed on audience analysis, outlining, designing and delivering a range of speeches. In addition, skills in overcoming nervousness, and developing confidence and a dynamic verbal profile in oral presentations will be covered.
goals: Learn effective techniques to control nervousness
Learn the art of mind-mapping, brainstorming, and outlining

**Course Description**

This course focuses on acquiring the skills of interpersonal communication and public speaking, which includes both building a speech and performing a speech. The two main types of public speech we will focus on are informative speeches and persuasive speeches.

**Attendance and Participation**

Students are expected to regularly attend and participate in class (the point of the class is to speak in public, after all). Almost every week, we will have a group activity that will help you practice your speaking skills, and you need to fully engage in these activities.

**Informative and Persuasive Speeches**

Students are required to give two major speeches: one informative and one persuasive. Each speech should be 10 minutes in length and you will be graded by the entire audience (not just me) on the following aspects: poise, voice, life, eye contact, gestures, and speed.

**Written Work**

Why is there written work in a speech class? Because to give a good speech, you need to be prepared. Building a good speech is the necessary foundation for performing the speech well. For each of the two major speeches, you will submit a written version of the speech that will be graded on the following aspects: content, organization, and visual aids. Just remember that when you _perform_ your speech, you should not read from or memorize the written speech.
